data.text: Aluminum (instead of Steel) Racks for Loaded Bike Tours

For those of you who tour with rear racks, is it courting disaster to go with an aluminum (instead of steel) rack? Specifically I will be on bumpy gravel, double track, and even some light singletrack. I have an aluminum rack already, but have heard they can be rather fragile when loaded up on bumpy stuff. Thanks!

Not necessarily. I depends on the brand. I have an Old Man Mountain rack that is aluminum and with the thru axle adaptor it is rated for 70lbs. Seems to be very durable and I've done some pretty serious trail riding with it. However, Surly makes some sick racks out of steel, which you can be certain will never break.
data.author: Christopher Adam

data.text: Aluminum cracks without announcement. Steel sometimes bends letting you know you've asked too much of it and you have some warning, but not always. I'd go steel, esp on rough terrain.
data.author: Tom Tomczyk

data.text: Anyone have a steel rack they'd recommend to fit with disc brakes? I've heard Tubus racks don't always fit well with discs.

data.text: Brad Landry they can fit very well but it depends a lot on placement of the rack attachment points which vary a lot between frames. I use Tubus racks on both Salsa Fargo and Kinesis ATR.
